data.learning_and_teaching_methods:
Students will participate in a range of formal, informal and innovative learning activities designed to develop the knowledge, understanding, skills and techniques required for successful participation in employment and/or further study.
All units in the course are supported by an online environment that facilitates communication between teaching staff and students and that provides access to resources such as class notes and recordings, readings, quizzes, discussion forums and assessment materials.
Learning activities used may include:

  • Case studies, which provide students with an opportunity to apply their knowledge to real or simulated scenarios independently or as members of a group.
  • Simulations modelled on real-life situations that promote integration of knowledge, skills and critical thinking.
  • Project work, which may be completed independently or involve group work. Projects assist students in developing more in-depth knowledge and skills needed to conduct research, to communicate effectively, to plan and organise activities and to manage time efficiently.
  • Readings taken from textbooks, journals, websites and other sources foster the development of concepts and knowledge drawn upon in individual units in the course.
  • Reflective activities, such as journals and guided reflections, assist students in integrating the course content and in developing the ability to transfer knowledge and skills from the learning environment into the workplace.
  • Self-study activities, such as questions with worked examples, (non assessed) online quizzes, and textbook questions and answers.
  • Online discussion forums, in which students may be required to submit responses to a given question, and/or to participate in the discussion of a set topic.

Learning may be facilitated through the following learning and teaching activities:

  • Group presentations and seminars designed to communicate and provide insight into key concepts and to assist in the understanding of the subject matter pertaining to a unit of study.
  • Tutorial-style activities that facilitate interactive learning and problem solving within a small group of students. These activities provide students with opportunities to contribute to discussions, ask questions, seek clarification, enhance their communication skills, and develop their ability to work in a collaborative manner with their peers.
  • Demonstration sessions that involve practical activities in well-equipped computer and physics laboratories: These sessions allow students to acquire and practise quantitative skills that are highly valued in the workplace and that they will need in the workplace upon graduation.
data.overview_and_aims_of_the_course:
The course provides an introduction to general Arts, Media and Communication studies. The course is equivalent to the first year of an undergraduate degree and will facilitate articulation into the second year of an undergraduate course offered by the Faculty of Arts.

Students will be introduced to fundamental knowledge and concepts in arts, media and communication, such as visual and digital media, media practice and production, critical thinking and modes of communication.
data.graduate_destinations_and_employability: Students who complete the Diploma of Arts Media and Communications may be eligible to articulate into selected Macquarie University's Bachelor Degrees.
data.admission_requirements:
• Year 12 (or equivalent) qualification with a minimum Selection Rank of 60

or

  • HSC (or interstate) board exam with minimum average mark* of 60.

International students must be at least 17 years of age at the time of commencement and have a qualification equivalent to Australian Year 12 with an ATAR of 60. 

*Other factors including ATAR and other attempted studies are taken into consideration with the average mark. Achieving the average mark does not guarantee an offer. Only relevant State Board approved academic subjects are included when reviewing your average. For instance, in the New South Wales HSC, only results from Category A and B Board Developed courses are considered.
data.ahegs_award_text: The Diploma of Arts Media and Communications is a diploma consisting of a minimum of 80 credit points, taught in English, which normally takes 28 weeks of full-time study or part-time equivalent. The course structure requires successful completion of eight units of study. Most students are admitted on the basis of successful completion of secondary studies or by alternative pathways for non-current school leavers. Graduates of the diploma program are eligible to progress to a range of bachelor degrees.
data.assessment:
Assessment tasks are designed to develop understanding and assess achievement of the course learning outcomes. They will
require students to integrate and exhibit skills and knowledge acquired. For each unit of study, students will complete
a variety of assessment tasks which may include the following:

  • Written assessments in traditional academic format ranging from short essays to longer, self-directed research papers, literature reviews and annotated bibliographies.
  • Written Case studies or Reports outlining the results of a detailed analysis of a situation based on empirical data and research. Case studies are used to assess analytical, critical thinking and research skills.
  • Assignments that entail the production of an Excel spreadsheet, the analysis of a mathematical problem or data set, or a brief written response to a topic question.
  • Online quizzes designed to assess knowledge, skills or capabilities, and typically consisting of a series of questions requiring brief responses or multiple choice questions.
  • Class participation, including engagement in tutorial and/or online discussions.
  • Written in-class tests, time limited assessments designed to assess students’ knowledge or skills.
  • Individual or group oral presentations which may incorporate digital technologies and be accompanied by handouts.
  • Final examination, an invigilated assessment conducted at the end of a term and designed to assess students’ body of knowledge and critical thinking skills.

learning_outcomes.description: Critically analyse topics related to arts, media and communication studies.
Recognise the social, cultural and political histories from which different media and modes of communication practices and structures have emerged.
Express ideas creatively and communicate those ideas with imagination.
Work productively in a group or team, showing abilities at different times to listen, contribute and lead effectively.
Use written, oral and visual communication skills to communicate information and ideas.
Apply basic research skills and methods to solve problems.
Reflect on ethical issues related to media information and its use.
Manage time and personnel resources effectively by drawing on planning, organisational, project management and leadership skills.
Explain some of the key theoretical concepts related to arts, media and communication.

As full credit does not apply, it will take up to 3 years to complete the degree following articulation from the Diploma.

articulations.course: Bachelor of Information Technology C000105 Active
articulations.articulation_conditions:
Successful completion of 8 units within this Diploma.

The Diploma of IT allows articulations into Bachelor of Information Technology with a major in:

  • Cyber Security
  • Data Science
  • Information Systems and Business Analysis
  • Software Technology
  • Web and Mobile App Development
articulations.details:
Up to 80 Credit points may be applied against the Bachelor degree based on successful completion of relevant Diploma units, however, there are essential units in the degree course which you must take in order to meet the requirements of the degree you want to articulate into.

Additionally, there are elective units in the degree course which you should take as they are the most relevant electives for the degree you want to articulate into.

Please see below what core units you must take and what elective unit you should take for the degree you want to articulate into:

  • For Bachelor of Information Technology with a Major in Cyber Security, students must take WMAT1007 and WCOM1010. To maximise credit transfer, students should take WCOM1011 and WSTA1250.
  • For Bachelor of Information Technology with a Major in Data Science, students must take WCOM1010 and WSTA1250.  To maximise credit transfer, students should take WCOM1011 and WCOM1750.
  • For Bachelor of Information Technology with a Major in Information Systems and Business Analysis, students must take WCOM1750 and WACC1000. To maximise credit transfer, students should take WCOM1011 and WSTA1250.
  • For Bachelor of Information Technology with a Major in Software Technology, students must take WMAT1007 and WCOM1010. To maximise credit transfer, students should take WCOM1011 and WSTA1250.
  • For Bachelor of Information Technology with a Web and Mobile App Development, students must take WCOM1010 and WCOM1750. To maximise credit transfer, students should take WCOM1011 and WSTA1250.

International students must be at least 17 years of age at the time of commencement and have a qualification equivalent to Australian Year 12 with an ATAR of 60. 

*Other factors including ATAR and other attempted studies are taken into consideration with the average mark. Achieving the average mark does not guarantee an offer. Only relevant State Board approved academic subjects are included when reviewing your average. For instance, in the New South Wales HSC, only results from Category A and B Board Developed courses are considered.

**Applicable from term 4 2021
data.ahegs_award_text: The Diploma of Engineering is a diploma consisting of a minimum of 80 credit points, taught in English, which normally takes 28 weeks of full-time study or part-time equivalent. The course structure requires successful completion of eight units of study. Most students are admitted on the basis of successful completion of secondary studies or by alternative pathways for non-current school leavers. Graduates of the diploma program are eligible to progress to a range of bachelor degrees.
data.assessment:
Assessment tasks are designed to develop understanding and assess achievement of the course learning outcomes. They will
require students to integrate and exhibit skills and knowledge acquired. For each unit of study, students will complete
a variety of assessment tasks which may include the following:

  • Written assessments in traditional academic format ranging from short essays to longer, self-directed research papers, literature reviews and annotated bibliographies.
  • Written Case studies or Reports outlining the results of a detailed analysis of a situation based on empirical data and research. Case studies are used to assess analytical, critical thinking and research skills.
  • Assignments that entail the production of an Excel spreadsheet, the analysis of a mathematical problem or data set, or a brief written response to a topic question.
  • Online quizzes designed to assess knowledge, skills or capabilities, and typically consisting of a series of questions requiring brief responses or multiple choice questions.
  • Class participation, including engagement in tutorial and/or online discussions.
  • Written in-class tests, time limited assessments designed to assess students’ knowledge or skills.
  • Individual or group oral presentations which may incorporate digital technologies and be accompanied by handouts.
  • Final examination, an invigilated assessment conducted at the end of a term and designed to assess students’ body of knowledge and critical thinking skills.

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate theoretical and practical knowledge in key engineering and related areas such as: electrical and mechanical concepts, computing, mathematics and physics.
Develop communication skills through teamwork and classroom presentations.
Work independently or collaboratively and manage time effectively.
Identify, analyse, interpret and apply engineering concepts, relevant data and information  to solve a diverse range of problems.
Use specialised technical skills and tools to analyse and explain data, to produce reports and to complete projects

data.learning_and_teaching_methods:
The program consists of formal scheduled classes and therefore involves face-to-face contact. Learning and teaching resources will be used as a basis for in-class teaching and team-based discussions of concepts and ideas in small peer groups and with the teachers.
Through small group project work, students will learn to collaborate with their peers and develop communication and problem solving skills.  Further study will take place individually through the use of online technologies. In addition, students will develop research skills through independent discovery and reading activities.
Depending on the chosen units of study, students may engage in laboratory work observing and undertaking experiments.

The Intensive program provides an academic entry pathway to a first year undergraduate degree program.

Assessment in the Foundation program closely mirrors assessment in tertiary studies to ensure students are adequately prepared for an undergraduate degree.

A wide variety of assessment methods are implemented such as essays, presentations, formal examinations, group work, practical projects, experimental work, debates, and research reports. Clear instructions as well as assessment standards and criteria for each assessment task will be provided.
Students will be given formative feedforward for each assessment task. This feedback will inform and guide their learning. Feedback may be provided in writing or verbally in discussion with peers and teachers.

data.title: Standard Foundation Program

container.title: Elective units
container.description: Complete 40 credit points from the following options.

data.learning_and_teaching_methods:
Students will participate in a range of formal, informal and innovative learning activities designed to develop the knowledge, understanding, skills and techniques required for successful participation in employment and/or further study.
All units in the course are supported by an online environment that facilitates communication between teaching staff and students and that provides access to resources such as class notes and recordings, readings, quizzes, discussion forums and assessment materials.
Learning activities used may include:

  • Case studies, which provide students with an opportunity to apply their knowledge to real or simulated scenarios independently or as members of a group.
  • Simulations modelled on real-life situations that promote integration of knowledge, skills and critical thinking.
  • Project work, which may be completed independently or involve group work. Projects assist students in developing more in-depth knowledge and skills needed to conduct research, to communicate effectively, to plan and organise activities and to manage time efficiently.
  • Readings taken from textbooks, journals, websites and other sources foster the development of concepts and knowledge drawn upon in individual units in the course.
  • Reflective activities, such as journals and guided reflections, assist students in integrating the course content and in developing the ability to transfer knowledge and skills from the learning environment into the workplace.
  • Self-study activities, such as questions with worked examples, (non assessed) online quizzes, and textbook questions and answers.
  • Online discussion forums, in which students may be required to submit responses to a given question, and/or to participate in the discussion of a set topic.

Learning may be facilitated through the following learning and teaching activities:

  • Group presentations and seminars designed to communicate and provide insight into key concepts and to assist in the understanding of the subject matter pertaining to a unit of study.
  • Tutorial-style activities that facilitate interactive learning and problem solving within a small group of students. These activities provide students with opportunities to contribute to discussions, ask questions, seek clarification, enhance their communication skills, and develop their ability to work in a collaborative manner with their peers.
  • Demonstration sessions that involve practical activities in well-equipped computer and physics laboratories: These sessions allow students to acquire and practise quantitative skills that are highly valued in the workplace and that they will need in the workplace upon graduation.
data.overview_and_aims_of_the_course: The aim of this course is to provide access to select units in the field of Engineering that constitute foundational study for individuals impacted by the COVID-19 emergency.  Successful completion of the Certificate provides candidates with a possible articulation pathway to further study in Higher Education.
data.graduate_destinations_and_employability: Students who complete the Undergraduate Certificate of Engineering may be eligible to articulate into selected Macquarie University's Bachelor Degrees.
data.admission_requirements:
• Year 12 (or equivalent) qualification with a minimum Selection Rank of 60, or

  • HSC (or interstate) board exam with minimum average mark* of 60.

  • HSC Mathematics Band 3 and above, or Extension 1 Band E2 and above, or Extension 2, or equivalent

*Other factors including ATAR and other attempted studies are taken into consideration with the average mark. Achieving the average mark does not guarantee an offer. Only relevant State Board approved academic subjects are included when reviewing your average. For instance, in the New South Wales HSC, only results from Category A and B Board Developed courses are considered.
data.ahegs_award_text: The Undergraduate Certificate of Engineering is a course consisting of a minimum of 40 credit points, taught in English, which normally takes 0.5 years of full-time study or part-time equivalent. The course structure requires successful completion of four units of study. Most students are admitted on the basis of successful completion of secondary studies or by alternative pathways for non-current school leavers. data.assessment:
Assessment tasks are designed to develop understanding and assess achievement of the course learning outcomes. They will
require students to integrate and exhibit skills and knowledge acquired. For each unit of study, students will complete
a variety of assessment tasks which may include the following:

  • Written assessments in traditional academic format ranging from short essays to longer, self-directed research papers, literature reviews and annotated bibliographies.
  • Written Case studies or Reports outlining the results of a detailed analysis of a situation based on empirical data and research. Case studies are used to assess analytical, critical thinking and research skills.
  • Assignments that entail the production of an Excel spreadsheet, the analysis of a mathematical problem or data set, or a brief written response to a topic question.
  • Online quizzes designed to assess knowledge, skills or capabilities, and typically consisting of a series of questions requiring brief responses or multiple choice questions.
  • Class participation, including engagement in tutorial and/or online discussions.
  • Written in-class tests, time limited assessments designed to assess students’ knowledge or skills.
  • Individual or group oral presentations which may incorporate digital technologies and be accompanied by handouts.
  • Final examination, an invigilated assessment conducted at the end of a term and designed to assess students’ body of knowledge and critical thinking skills.

course_notes.note:
WMAT1010 will not count to the core zone of the Bachelor of Engineering (Honours) course so will count to the flexible zone. It will count for the other 4 specialisations.

Note that WPHY1510 will not count for the Software Engineering specialisation so will count to the flexible zone if the student chooses that specialisation.

data.learning_and_teaching_methods:
Students will participate in a range of formal, informal and innovative learning activities designed to develop the knowledge, understanding, skills and techniques required for successful participation in employment and/or further study.
All units in the course are supported by an online environment that facilitates communication between teaching staff and students and that provides access to resources such as class notes and recordings, readings, quizzes, discussion forums and assessment materials.
Learning activities used may include:

  • Case studies, which provide students with an opportunity to apply their knowledge to real or simulated scenarios independently or as members of a group.
  • Simulations modelled on real-life situations that promote integration of knowledge, skills and critical thinking.
  • Project work, which may be completed independently or involve group work. Projects assist students in developing more in-depth knowledge and skills needed to conduct research, to communicate effectively, to plan and organise activities and to manage time efficiently.
  • Readings taken from textbooks, journals, websites and other sources foster the development of concepts and knowledge drawn upon in individual units in the course.
  • Reflective activities, such as journals and guided reflections, assist students in integrating the course content and in developing the ability to transfer knowledge and skills from the learning environment into the workplace.
  • Self-study activities, such as questions with worked examples, (non assessed) online quizzes, and textbook questions and answers.
  • Online discussion forums, in which students may be required to submit responses to a given question, and/or to participate in the discussion of a set topic.

Learning may be facilitated through the following learning and teaching activities:

  • Group presentations and seminars designed to communicate and provide insight into key concepts and to assist in the understanding of the subject matter pertaining to a unit of study.
  • Tutorial-style activities that facilitate interactive learning and problem solving within a small group of students. These activities provide students with opportunities to contribute to discussions, ask questions, seek clarification, enhance their communication skills, and develop their ability to work in a collaborative manner with their peers.
  • Demonstration sessions that involve practical activities in well-equipped computer and physics laboratories: These sessions allow students to acquire and practise quantitative skills that are highly valued in the workplace and that they will need in the workplace upon graduation.
